fields.description:
When a build plan throws the _Unable to detect changes_ error, a notification is not sent although the plan is configured to send notification for Job Errors.

{quote}Bamboo will send a notification whenever an error occurs in one of the plan's job build processes (i.e. the activities that Bamboo performs to run a job build). This event is not related to failures of the actual build itself (see the Failed Jobs And First Successful and Failed Builds And First Successful events above). For example, a notification will be sent if Bamboo encounters an error when connecting to the repository, or detecting changes.{quote}
https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/configuring-notifications-for-a-plan-and-its-jobs-289276973.html

The following can be observed in Bamboo logs when a Job Error happens:

fields.description:
Hi,

today I found a Bug, which is basically related to Dedicated Agent synchronization Problem for Deployment jobs and the lack of required capability information for Deployment Jobs.

h3. The Situation:
So I had this Deployment Job which didn't run on any Agent any more even though I was pretty sure there are capable Agents (as the Build job requires exactly the same capabilities).

h3. The Issue
Sometimes (basically pretty often) it happens, that if you remove a dedicated Agent from a Deployment Environment Job at the Job Edit Page, that the Agent is still dedicated but not shown any more on the Environment Detail page.

If that happens and this dedicated Agent (or multiple Agents) are disabled or offline its really hard to figure out the Problem why the Job can't be run anymore. A quickfix could be to dedicate another Agent (what would be in my case to expensive as all these agents are needed to build Buildplans).

h3. Fix

I had to clone the Deployment Job, remove all Tasks, so I could see the only capable and dedicated Agent, so I could go to the Agent Admin page and remove the dedication there. After that everything works fine.


Hope this Description helps others because it took me quite some time to figure this out. Also it would be great of you guys, if you could do two things:
# Show all required Capabilities for a deployment Job like its done for Build Jobs
# Fix the Dedication synchronisation Problem




My Bamboo Version: Atlassian Bamboo version 5.8.1 build 5866 - 17 Mar 15
fields.summary: Dedicated Agent synchronization problem for deployment projects

fields.description: If I have 6 tasks running and they are long, and one fails due to an infrastructure failure, I'd like to be able to rerun it in parallel with the other 5 so my real result arrives earlier, rather than having to wait for the whole build to finish before rerunning that one task.
fields.summary: Please add the ability to kick off a rerun before all tasks are finished.

fields.description:
After creating a plan and a deployment project using the plan, it's possible to delete the plan, leaving the project without a plan.

This seems to be a expected, as this message is shown when the plan is deleted:
{quote}
Deployment projects related to this plan
The following deployment projects are related to this plan and will not run when this plan is removed:
My Deployment Project
{quote}

However, this is causing bugs like [this one|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-16000] when cloning or the following stacktrace when creating an environment, failing to create it:
{noformat}

	at org.apache.struts2.interceptor.ServletConfigInterceptor.intercept(ServletConfigInterceptor.java:164)

	at org.apache.struts2.impl.StrutsActionProxy.execute(StrutsActionProxy.java:54)
	at org.apache.struts2.dispatcher.Dispatcher.serviceAction(Dispatcher.java:564)
	at org.apache.struts2.dispatcher.ng.ExecuteOperations.executeAction(ExecuteOperations.java:77)
	at org.apache.struts2.dispatcher.ng.filter.StrutsExecuteFilter.doFilter(StrutsExecuteFilter.java:93)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.ApplicationFilterChain.internalDoFilter(ApplicationFilterChain.java:235)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.ApplicationFilterChain.doFilter(ApplicationFilterChain.java:206)
	at com.atlassian.plugin.servlet.filter.IteratingFilterChain.doFilter(IteratingFilterChain.java:46)
	at com.atlassian.plugin.servlet.filter.DelegatingPluginFilter$1.doFilter(DelegatingPluginFilter.java:70)
	at com.atlassian.labs.botkiller.BotKillerFilter.doFilter(BotKillerFilter.java:36)
	at com.atlassian.plugin.servlet.filter.DelegatingPluginFilter.doFilter(DelegatingPluginFilter.java:78)
{noformat}

This is both not expected (a stacktrace is definitively not an expected behavior), prevents the users from completely using the system and it's now clear on how to fix it.

*Steps to reproduce*
# Create a build plan 
# Create a deployment project using that plan
# Delete the plan
# Clone project or try to set an environment

*Expected behavior*
Expected behaviors may be:
# Prevent users from doing the operation while the project doesn't have a plan
# Prevent users from editing the project at all while it doesn't have a plan
# Prevent plan from being deleted while it's associated with deployment projects
# Ask customer to set the plan in the deployment project before continuing with the operations
# Have all operations work even without a plan

*Actual outcome*
* In both cases (and probably in other situations) a stack trace is shown and the operation is not completed 

*Workaround*
* Set a plan before cloning/setting and environment

fields.description:
Sometimes a released version is removed from the download archive.
E.g. shortly after releasing 5.9.2 it was discovered that one of the bugfixing had not made it correctly in the release.
Version 5.9.2 was removed, and replaced with a fixed 5.9.3.
Users that downloaded the now non-existent version 5.9.2 get an alarming message in the "Manage add-ons" screen:
{panel}
This version of Bamboo is unrecognized by the Atlassian Marketplace. It might be a non-standard build or be too new to appear.
{panel}
Version 5.9.2 should still be a valid version for Marketplace, and should not be bothered by the fact that it's no longer available for download.
fields.summary: When a released version is removed from download archive, Marketplace reports it as unrecognized

fields.description:
1. Execute a job that produces a tar archive as an artifact on a win7 agent via a script task "tar -czf <some directory with multiple large files>"
2. Download said artifact in a job that runs on win8 agent.
3. Untar and observe.

Expected Results:
The archive expands appropriately.

Actual Results:
task and job fail with "tar: Archive value xxxxxxxx is out of gid_t range 0..65535" 

Note: performing the untarring manually on cygwin does not produce the error.
fields.summary: Untarring an Archive on Windows 8 Fails with 'out of gid_t range' error

fields.description:
h3. Summary

This is thrown by Bamboo on each poll of an SVN repo that has no changes, so for an active instance this can easily clutter the logs and grow them more than necessary. 

Current thought is that 
{code}
com.atlassian.bamboo.v2.trigger.DefaultChangeDetectionManager.filterExcludedChangesets(DefaultChangeDetectionManager.java:759)
{code} seems to be accepting a null where it shouldn't.

h3. Environment
SVN 1.7

h3. Steps to Reproduce
We have not been able to reproduce this locally yet.

h3. Expected Results
No issue.

h3. Actual Results
{code}
[10-BAM::PlanExec:pool-17-thread-2] [DefaultErrorHandler] Recording an error: Unable to detect changes : XXXX-XXXX : java.lang.NullPointerException
{code}
 
h3. Notes

h3.Workarounds
 - (May not work in all cases) Remove the linked repository and re-add it
fields.summary: SVN polls with no changes result in NPE
Collapse code in region blocks for powershell inline scripts

fields.description:
As a bamboo user with intermittent test failures, I'd like to run additional test runs when there is nothing in the queue for an agent, or there hasn't been anything in the queue for a long time, so that I can take advantage of agents on idle.

Builds that are executed from this trigger would by default have lower priority than any other build in the queue available for the agent.

I need to be able to define parameters for the idle time, like how long it is before a build is idle for this use-case. I need to be able to define this as a special trigger for a given plan.
fields.summary: Agent-Idle state as a build trigger

fields.description:
When stopping an active build via the Web UI, the bamboo agent kills processes of the shell script invocations it directly spawned, but does not kill any of that shell script's subprocesses (which may be blocked or hung).  These processes (or process hierarchies) become children of init (pid 1) until an admin notices them and manually kills them.  Depending on what resources are held by these processes, subsequent builds may fail.

The bamboo agent should spawn its processes in a separate process group, so that it can raise the kill signal to all processes within the process group.
fields.summary: Stopping an active build does not kill all running Tasks' subprocesses

fields.description: Further to BAM-15506, Bamboo still OOMEs for large numbers of tests when the tests have long names, such as parameterized tests where the parameter values are used in the the test case "name".
fields.summary: Bamboo OOMEs when dealing with large numbers of parameterized tests

fields.description:
This is related to BAM-16190 / BAM-12121  

Can the new AWS M4 instance types be added to be bamboo UI menu.

The instance types are:
m4.large
m4.xlarge
m4.2xlarge
m4.4xlarge
m4.10xlarge
fields.summary: Add M4 AWS Instance types to the Bamboo UI

fields.description: Some teams run tens of thousands of tests during the course of a single build. It becomes quite a mess when specific test results need to be viewed from the UI. Implementing the ability to search for specific test results under a test class would definitely help mitigate that issue.
fields.summary: Add ability to search for test results on a test class

fields.description:
Our team uses multiple post build events in visual studio projects where they use the $(SolutionDir) environment variable to help define the path to the .sln. When Bamboo builds the .sln it does not capture the value of $(SolutionDir) and subsequently causes "Undefined"../Bin/Release 
The "Undefined" is supposed to be the value of ($SolutionDir).
Can you please make it that all the env variables on msbuild and devenv are available in Bamboo.
Also I tried to define the ($SolutionDir) myself but you can only set alphanumeric values. Can you please make it available so that we can set any type of global variable that we want in bamboo.
fields.summary: Please make $(SolutionDir) value accessible in Bamboo.

fields.description:
Some Bamboo Cloud instances don't have Artifact Storage feature enabled. The feature is officially documented here - https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOOCLOUD/Amazon+S3+artifact+storage

*WORKAROUND*
For Bamboo Cloud users, please raise a support ticket at https://support.atlassian.com to request for this feature to be enabled by Atlassian Cloud support.
fields.summary: Bamboo Cloud instances don't have Artifact Storage feature enabled

running command line: \n/opt/grails-2.4/bin/grails upgrade -force -non-interactive
....

fields.description:
Currently, Bamboo does not check if the particular branch contains the same code with other branches. This will cause duplicate build of the same code if other branch is at the same revision.

Bamboo could run a pre build task to check if other branch plans have the build results for the revision number
fields.summary: Check if the revision number has been built before in other branch plans before starting a build

fields.summary: Failed to start elastic instances: Error when starting a new instance

fields.description:
Guide: https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Specifying+a+backup+schedule

Please specify what and how the *Wait for jobs to complete* option works.
fields.summary: DOCUMENTATION: Specifying a backup schedule

fields.description:
When a new plan branch is set up, the default Notification setting is to notify committers and people who have favorited the branch. This default should be changed to "Use the Plan's Settings". The plan settings exist to act as a default and it's not obvious to a new user that the plan settings are not being applied to new branches until they find this setting. I keep having to go into plans and fix this setting as I find plans that were not set up correctly.

It would be a better approach to have the default notification settings for a new plan be set to notify committers and people who favorited. I also think it's important to have notifications go out by default in this fashion for the beginner users to not have to configure this setting, but I think setting it as a default plan notification scheme is a much better option.
fields.summary: Use Plan Notification Scheme by Default for New Branch

fields.description:
h2. Description
When creating AppLinks between Bamboo and another Atlassian application going through a proxy set up with SNI, the AppLinks won't work properly.

This issue is caused by the commons-httpclient version (3.0.1) used by Bamboo, which does not have support for TLS - SNI.

h3. Environment
Java version 1.7 or newer (starting from the java version 1.7 TLS 1.1 and 1.2 are disabled by default).

h3. Expected results
The AppLink can be successfully created.

h3. Actual results
It is not possible to successfully create an AppLink and the following stack trace can be found in the {{atlassian-bamboo.log}}
{noformat}
2015-09-01 17:02:29,222 ERROR [http-bio-8085-exec-11] [CreateApplicationLinkUIResource] ManifestNotFoundException thrown while retrieving manifest
com.atlassian.applinks.spi.manifest.ManifestNotFoundException: javax.net.ssl.SSLHandshakeException: No appropriate protocol (protocol is disabled or cipher suites are inappropriate)
    at com.atlassian.applinks.core.manifest.AppLinksManifestDownloader.download1(AppLinksManifestDownloader.java:201)
    at com.atlassian.applinks.core.manifest.AppLinksManifestDownloader.access$000(AppLinksManifestDownloader.java:44)
    at com.atlassian.applinks.core.manifest.AppLinksManifestDownloader$1$1.<init>(AppLinksManifestDownloader.java:86)
    at com.atlassian.applinks.core.manifest.AppLinksManifestDownloader$1.apply(AppLinksManifestDownloader.java:79)
    at com.atlassian.applinks.core.manifest.AppLinksManifestDownloader$1.apply(AppLinksManifestDownloader.java:76)
    at com.google.common.collect.ComputingConcurrentHashMap$ComputingValueReference.compute(ComputingConcurrentHashMap.java:355)
    at com.google.common.collect.ComputingConcurrentHashMap$ComputingSegment.compute(ComputingConcurrentHashMap.java:184)
...
...
{noformat}

h3. Notes
{panel}
(i) This ticket is about the link from Bamboo to another Atlassian application.
The improvement related to the connection from JIRA to Bamboo (or any other Atlassian applications) is described here JRA-24515.
{panel}

h3. Workarounds
{panel}
(i) As this issue is fixed, please consider upgrading before applying any of the following workarounds.
{panel}

The following workaround options are alternatives, please choose the best one for your case.

+Workaround - option #1+
Use a newer {{commons-httpclient}} jar version (you need at least version {{3.1-atlassian-2}}) by following these steps:

# # Shutdown Bamboo
# Download this [commons-httpclient-3.1-atlassian-2.jar|https://maven.atlassian.com/content/repositories/atlassian-3rdparty/commons-httpclient/commons-httpclient/3.1-atlassian-2/commons-httpclient-3.1-atlassian-2.jar] into the machine hosting Bamboo
# Backup and delete {{/opt/atlassian/bamboo/atlassian-bamboo/WEB-INF/lib/commons-httpclient-3.0.1.jar}}
# Move the file {{commons-httpclient-3.1-atlassian-2.jar}} into the directory {{/opt/atlassian/bamboo/atlassian-bamboo/WEB-INF/lib}}
# Restart Bamboo

+Workaround - option #2+
Add the following Java properties to the [Bamboo Java properties|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/configuring-bamboo-on-start-up-289277345.html]:
{code}
-Dhttps.protocols=TLSv1.1,TLSv1.2
{code}

+Workaround - option #3+
Connect the Atlassian applications bypassing the proxy.

You can find the instructions describing the changes required to your environment, and how to recreate the AppLinks bypassing the proxy here:
[How to create an unproxied Application Link|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/KB/How+to+create+an+unproxied+Application+Link]

fields.description:
Documentation of Plan Branches does not mention the limitation that only the primary repository is monitored for branches.

When a Plan has multiple source repositories only the first one is monitored for Plan Branches.  This limitation should be added to the table at [Limitations with plan branches|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO058/Using+plan+branches#Usingplanbranches-Limitationswithplanbranches].

This change should be made in all the doc versions that support Plan Branches, e.g. 4.0 and up.

*Suggested Text (for new table row)*

Action: Branches from Multiple Repositories
Limitations: Only the primary repository is monitored for new branches.

Cheers,
Morgan.
fields.summary: Documentation of Plan Branches does not mention limitation, only the primary repository is monitored for branches.

fields.description: When Bamboo is not cleanly shutdown before a reboot (usually because of Azure VM maintenance), the VM irrecoverably hangs on shutdown (assumption. Might be during another phase). The only solution is to delete the VM, then remount the VHD onto a new instance. A "hard reboot" of the VM through the CLI/portal does not fix it. This effectively kills our ability to use Bamboo.
fields.summary: Azure VM Hangs on Shutdown

fields.description:
At the moment it's possible to only terminate instances via UI ("Manage Elastic Instances"). Also the automatic instance management does a termination. I think also the schedules do a termination (correct me if I'm wrong). 
But e.g. a standard use case today is to use Docker and since your standard AMI has not nearly the latest Docker version this needs to be updated manually. Unfortunately this is done on the root file system - and this gets dumped if the instance is terminated :(

fields.description:
I have a deployment plan, which pulls a docker image and runs it. Then it does a health check to make sure the service came back healthy.

If the health check fails, then I want to automatically trigger a rollback to the previous version. Is there a way to set this up in Bamboo? Triggers seem to allow deploying on a schedule or after a successful build, but I could not find any documentation on triggering a rollback after a failed deployment. This will be great to automate the push/build/deploy and recovery pipeline. 

I looked at this other case which was linked from a stackoverflow post which did not help, https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-14079
fields.summary: Trigger a rollback automatically if deployment plan fails

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Currently there is no way to report on build times within Bamboo.  There is an "Build Duration" report but this is defined as the queue time plus the build time.  As queue times are affected by activity across all the builds it is difficult to analyze build time or see if it is negatively affected by code changes.

There is also an Improvement request to separate these two values: [BAM-10938|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-10938]

h3. Suggested Solution

Please implement a report similar to Build Duration which shows the Build Time.

Alternatively, update the [Build Times Plugin|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.atlassian.bamboo.plugin%3Abamboo-build-times-plugin/versions] for compatibility with Bamboo 5.x.  The Build Times Plugin is referenced from [Bamboo Best Practice - Using Agents|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Bamboo+Best+Practice+-+Using+Agents#BambooBestPractice-UsingAgents-Buildtimesplugin] but it is not compatible with Bamboo 5.x.

h3. Workaround

# Copy data from the Build Duration report and paste into a spreadsheet.
# Copy data from the Build Queued Duration report and paste alongside the Duration times.
# Subtrace the Build Queue Duration from the Build Duration to find the build time.

NOTE: Firefox is helpful for this because it enables you to [select columns of text|http://www.alvinpoh.com/how-to-select-columns-of-text-in-your-browser-firefox/].
fields.summary: Ability to report on build times within Bamboo

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When exclusions are defined for a repository, revisions that contain only changes to excluded material do not trigger a build.  These revisions also do not appear in the Revisions tab or the Issues tab even though all revisions since the last build are included in the build.

This behavior does not match the text in the UI : "Customise what files Bamboo uses to detect changes." ([screenshot|https://www.evernote.com/l/AAQR9UC-4mxPJI4O-lO9Xh1VoP8HjuIv6Do])

There is no documentation which covers this unexpected effect of excluding files/directories from build triggering.

h3. Environment
* Bamboo 5.7.2
* Subversion

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a build plan.
# Create a global repository.
# Under "Advanced" for the new repo enter a regular expression to exlude files from build triggering.
# Create an excluded file and commit the change, referencing a JIRA issue in a comment.
# Create an included file and commit the change.

The last commit will trigger the build but the prior commit and the issue it references will not appear in the build results.

h3. Expected Results
* Revisions excluded from build triggering should appear in the Revisions tab because those changes are present in the build.
* Issues mentioned in revisions excluded from build triggering should appear in the Issues tab because those changes are present in the build.

h3. Actual Results
* Revisions excluded from build triggering also do not appear in the Revisions and Issues tabs.
 
h3. Example Use Case

A project where UI work is being done by one team and all the backend work done by another. The UI work will not use Integration testing and unit testing so the dev team does not want the UI work to trigger build/deployments (as this will trigger unit tests which are unnecessary). However, we do want to know what commits are in the build regardless of whether they were the trigger for the build or not. They are still significant changes just not the primary.

h3.Workaround
No workaround has been identified.
fields.summary: Exclusion from build triggering causes exclusion from build results Revisions and Issues tabs

fields.description:
(Background, I opened a support issue and was asked to open a ticket instead https://support.atlassian.com/servicedesk/customer/portal/23/JST-151976)

I am trying to setup a CI job for a Python project which depends on numpy.

In our plan, we ensure each build does a clean checkout. It then goes on to install requirements via pip.

Since numpy takes considerable amount of time to install when using pip (~5m on m3.medium because the package is downloaded as source and is recompiled each time), too speed up the CI cycle, we decided to have it preinstall by using yum install during the startup script.

Subsequently, the plan will continue and install the remaining dependencies – which includes numpy. Typically in most Fedora/CentOS/RHEL bases systems, pip will see the system package present and will not reinstall it again.

However, in this case, something is wrong and numpy is reinstall again by pip.

This significantly affects our CI turnaround time as the build only takes 6 mins, with 5 min being spent installing numpy!
fields.summary: Elastic Bamboo stock image Python pip problem

fields.description:
When using the CodeDeploy task in Bamboo 5.9.3, hidden files will not be archived/pushed to S3 when running a deployment.

According to the documentation at http://docs.aws.amazon.com/codedeploy/latest/userguide/how-to-push-revision.html the {{--ignore-hidden-files}} flag is optional, but it appears to be always-on in Bamboo's CodeDeploy task. 

This causes issues when deploying (uncompressed) website sources that contain a {{.htaccess}} file for example.

In my opinion hidden files should be included by default, or there would have to be a checkbox option to enable/disable hidden files when configuring the task.

Proof:

Source directory on the Bamboo agent that runs the CodeDeploy task:

{code}
root@agent02:/home/bamboo/bamboo-agent-home/xml-data/build-dir/48758785-48889857/Web# ls -lsa
total 40
4 drwxr-xr-x 6 bamboo bamboo 4096 Aug 10 13:06 .
4 drwxr-xr-x 4 bamboo bamboo 4096 Aug 10 13:06 ..
8 -rw-r--r-- 1 bamboo bamboo 5050 Aug  7 14:06 .htaccess
4 -rw-r--r-- 1 bamboo bamboo 1115 Apr 28 11:53 index.php
4 drwxr-xr-x 4 bamboo bamboo 4096 Aug 10 13:00 Packages
4 -rw-r--r-- 1 bamboo bamboo   25 Aug  7 14:06 robots.txt
4 drwxr-xr-x 7 bamboo bamboo 4096 Aug 10 13:06 typo3
4 drwxr-xr-x 3 bamboo bamboo 4096 Aug 10 13:06 typo3conf
4 drwxr-xr-x 4 bamboo bamboo 4096 Aug 10 13:06 typo3_src
{code}

Then, after deployment on an EC2 instance, in CodeDeploy's cache folder which is used as source where {{appspec.yml}} copies it's files from:

{code}
[root@dii-usnv-web-t3ws-04 Web]# pwd
/opt/codedeploy-agent/deployment-root/b1275288-2281-4ec4-97f4-174779de10bd/d-EBBJ5EJLA/deployment-archive/Web
[root@dii-usnv-web-t3ws-04 Web]# ls -lsa
totaal 20
0 drwxr-xr-x. 6 root root   98 10 aug 11:08 .
0 drwxr-xr-x. 4 root root   48 10 aug 11:08 ..
4 -rw-r--r--. 1 root root 1115 10 aug 11:08 index.php
0 drwxr-xr-x. 4 root root   39 10 aug 11:08 Packages
4 -rw-r--r--. 1 root root   25 10 aug 11:08 robots.txt
4 drwxr-xr-x. 7 root root 4096 10 aug 11:08 typo3
4 drwxr-xr-x. 3 root root 4096 10 aug 11:08 typo3conf
4 drwxr-xr-x. 4 root root 4096 10 aug 11:08 typo3_src
[root@dii-usnv-web-t3ws-04 Web]#
{code}

The {{.htaccess}} file was not deployed to the webserver, not copied to the siteroot, caused the ELB health check to fail and the instance not to come online in it's ELB group. Because the deployment is 'green' according to both CodeDeploy and Bamboo, it went ahead and deployed all other EC2 instances in the same fashion, causing every single webserver to go down in the ELB group. Not good!

~Note: The deployment appears to be 2 hours earlier than the source in Bamboo, but this due to UTC vs CEST timezone differences on the machines.~
fields.summary: CodeDeploy task ommits hidden files

fields.description:
Occasionally we observe jobs that become stuck during the "Updating source code to latest" phase after they have been picked up from the build queue. This most often coincides with when our Stash instance is upgraded.

We would expected a Stash upgrade to cause the source code checkout to simply fail and/or retry a few times, but not hang indefinitely.

We have seen jobs sit there for many days before being manually stopped. In many cases, the underlying elastic agent running the job will have gone offline, but the job still hangs there. Notably the job will not appear in that agent's build history though.

(This is not a new issue but I think this is the first time we've raised it. It's been happening sporadically for maybe the last year.)
fields.summary: Job stuck "Updating source code to latest" forever

fields.description:
The http://myhost.com:8085/bamboo/rest/api/latest/result/projectKey-buildKey-buildNumber/comment resource permits adding comments to a build, but there does not appear to be an equivalent resource for adding comments to a deployment release/version.

Our use case is that we are using the REST API to chain a successful deployment to a build plan (for testing purposes).  This permits us to run integration/functional and load tests against an environment after the deployment.  If this API call existed, a script in the build plan could callback to the version and add a comment with a link to the build/test results.

fields.description:
The Stock elastic image ami-1f750268 (other Windows images may also be affected) has a default service that updates the instance once it starts. This process in taking up almost all CPU time, affecting performance and making build not run correctly.

Since when instances are restarted all changes are undone, disabling update once won't help as new instances will still have the service running.

Modifying the stock image is necessary, so it doesn't run this service.

*Workaround*

_Create a custom image from that Stock image_
# Start the stock instance
# Disable updates:
{code}
reg add "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\WindowsUpdate\Auto Update" /v AUOptions /t REG_DWORD /d 1 /f  
{code}
or the whole service like this
{code}
sc config wuauserv start= disabled
{code}
# Create a custom image from that image in Bamboo and use this one
fields.summary: Stock Windows elastic image ami-1f750268 is running update which is taking a lot of CPU time

fields.description:
When a user re-create a Linked Repository and re-associate it with the target Plan, branches checkout from incorrect branch.

h5. Steps to reproduce

# Create a Project & Plan.
# Set up a Linked Repository (e.g. Bitbucket) - Don't enable the plan just yet.
# Create a Plan branch - Bamboo will automatically configure the {{Plan branch >> Source repository}} to override the plan's default repository and checkout from the 'branch' in question.
# Run a build in the Plan branch - works fine!
# For any particular reason, remove the Linked Repository (e.g. Bitbucket) associated to this Plan directly in {{Bamboo administration >> Linked repositories}}.
# The Plan will become 'repository' orphan, check in {{Plan Configuration >> repositories}}.
# However, the Plan branch still show the repository configuration inside {{Plan branch >> Source repository}}.
# Go back to {{Bamboo administration >> Linked repositories}} and recreate the repository (either using the same name or not).
# Go back to the Plan and access the {{Plan Configuration >> Repositories}} page to reassociate the repository to the plan.
# As stated in Step 7, the Plan branch will have the old repository configuration inside {{Plan branch >> Source repository}}.
# To reload the repository configuration:
#* Uncheck the 'Override the plan's default repository' option and save the page. 
#* Check the 'Override the plan's default repository' option and save page.
# The page will display the new repository configuration.

The new repository configuration page should give you the option to select the branch of your choice. If we were previously building the 'develop' branch, then we should be able to select the 'develop' branch now. However, at this point we are no longer able to select the 'Branch' we want to associate with the Plan branch, the field only displays the 'master' branch, and if you try to 'Load Repositories' to refresh the list of branches, Bamboo throws a {{'No repositories found for user 'username'.'}} error.

h5. Workaround

# We can try the 'Change password' option to reload the configurations/branches from the repository (e.g. Bitbucket), the problem is that this doesn't seem to work consistently, some times the option to change the 'Branch' becomes greyed out and some times it works. (i) As a tip, you can also try to reload the configuration and change the 'Repository' field, this will unlock the 'Branch' field and you will be able to select your repository again and the target branch. [BAM-17087|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-17087]
# You can also try to delete the Plan branch and recreate it. This way Bamboo will automatically create the repository configuration for the Plan branch.
fields.summary: Re-associate Linked Repositories to Plans cause branches to checkout from incorrect branch

fields.description:
Artifacts are removed from deploy working directory after source code checkout task. When the following two things hold true, artifacts are not downloaded:

1. Deploy runs on a local agent.
2. Deploy plan checks out source code *after* it downloads artifacts.

Note that check out source code *IS NOT* forcing a clean build, so the user expects that downloaded artifacts are inside the working directory - but they are not.

h6. Steps to reproduce

1. Have a build plan produce a shared artifact containing a few files.
2. Create a Deployment project and set the source build plan to be the one from Step 1.
3. Create a test Environment and configure the tasks from the Environment to look like this:

!env-tasks.png|thumbnail!

(i) In this case I created a simple _Script_ task to display the files inside the deploy working directory using: {{ls -la}}.

4. Deploy the Environment.

According to the logs all tasks have been successful. However, looking at the output from the {ls -la}} script or even navigating to the {{<bamboo-home>/xml-data/build-dir/<deployment-id>}} directory directly, artifacts are missing. The only files inside the deploy working directory are the ones checked out from the _Source Code Checkout_ task.

h6. Workaround

Looks like we have two workarounds:

1. Running the same build plan & deployment project using a remote agent, rather than a local agent, works fine. There's no need to set up the remote agent on a different machine, you can install the remote agent in the same machine where Bamboo is running.

2. Re-ordering the tasks and placing the _Source Code Checkout_ task to happen *after* the _Artifact Download_ task, works fine.
fields.summary: Artifacts are removed from deploy working directory after source code checkout task

fields.description:
http://blog.swisstech.net/2012/12/environments-in-tanuki-softwares-java.html?m=1

{quote}tanukisoftwaresupport December 26, 2012 at 3:22 AM
Hi, 

What version of the Java Service Wrapper are you using?
This bug should have already been fixed since version 3.3.0. 

Best Regards, 
Tanuki Software Support Team

Reply

tanukisoftwaresupport December 26, 2012 at 3:33 AM
Sorry, I forgot to mention it in my first post. To fix the issue yourself with the 3.2.* version of the script, please open the checkUser() function and change the following line:
su -m $RUN_AS_USER -c "\"$REALPATH\" $2"
to:
su - $RUN_AS_USER -c "\"$REALPATH\" $2"
{quote}

This appears to have been fixed in the service wrapper for some time, and while the workaround is pretty simple, it took hours for me to find it.
fields.summary: Update service wrapper for remote agents - not using environment variables

fields.description:
Our build server is used to kick off tests that sometimes take up to 20 hours.  If something is incorrectly configured, the test will fail immediately.  In some cases, this tricks Bamboo into thinking that the test execution time should be 1 minute long.  As a result, Bamboo says that a 20 hour test is extremely overrun.  This alone is not a problem as we understand the nature of the issue.  

However Bamboo is also indicating that the build itself is hung, implying that no log messages have been received for a very long time.  While in the Job Summary tab, it is very clear that logs are still coming in, as they are scrolling along the screen as the test is still running.  It seems like Bamboo is unable to recognize these as log messages.  This might be more of a support request than a bug, but it seems like we're doing everything that we should be doing, so I put it here first.  

See the attached screenshots
fields.summary: Build job incorrectly reporting hung build

fields.description:
Depending on the size of the instance, the backup might take 50 plus minutes to complete. Also the time it takes for the server to go into backup may take an additional hour or more as it waits for existing jobs to finish, so the down time is ~ 2hrs plus. 

Customers who implement [High Availability|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/High_availability] have might have a target of 99.9% uptime on the system that equates to ~2min downtime for per day for backup. 

The backup mechanism should be improved to reduce down time anywhere between 15 to 2 min per day to fit with 99% to 99.9% percent up time SLA.
fields.summary: Reduce the backup time

fields.description:
h4. Problem

Git operations (checkout, merge) are taking an inordinately long time on the Bamboo server compared to command line. These should take seconds, not minutes for a ~120 MB repository. Since merging happens before the builds starts the build request won't appear in the queue until these Git operations have been completed.

Note: This is with automatic branch merging enabled
fields.summary: Improve performance of branch merging

fields.description:
Commit records are removed when build expiration is run. Having this set to a very short period, will mean that current builds or releases may demonstrate missing commits when comparing current and previous releases for example.

The immediate work around for this is to extend the expiration period, thus keeping records for longer while more recent releases are relevant, however this will still ultimately lead to possible gaps in commit history, so ultimately caparison of two prior releases may not be complete.
fields.summary: Build expiration should not remove commit history for releases

fields.description:
This ticket has been cloned from https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSD-1305
as per
https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSD-1305?focusedCommentId=752677&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-752677

h4. Summary:
any issue operations such as *commenting* or *resolve/reopen issue using transition button* for *Service Desk enabled projects* in *IE 11* causes the browser to hang. After refreshing the page, user can see that the operation was actually successfully done (the comment gets posted, status gets changed, etc).

h4. Steps to reproduce:
# Open any issue in *Service Desk Project* (from agent's issue view page)
# Perform any operation, lets say, click on *Resolve issue* button
# Enter comment (optional)
# Click on *Resolve this issue* button
# JIRA will stay on that page, as shown below
!stop.png|thumbnail!
# Refresh the page (F5)
# The status was actually changed to *Resolved*, and the *comment* got posted

h4. Error thrown
Activating the developer tool shows 
{code}
Unableto get property 'removeChild' of undefined or null reference
File: batch.js, Line: 139, Column: 394 
{code}
as shown in the screenshot below
!js.png|thumbnail!

h4. Additional information:
Reproducible in IE 11 only
Does not happen with other version of IE and other browsers
Happen only to Service Desk Project (other projects work fine)
Tested with JIRA 6.3.10 and 6.3.11

h4. Workaround
In the developer tool (Emulation)
- Change the *Document Mode* and *User Agent String* to other version of IE (such as IE 10) as shown below
!mode.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Bamboo Panel cause Issue Operations do not work properly in IE11

fields.description:
From the page http://jdbc.postgresql.org/download.html:
{quote}
If you are using the 1.6 then you should use the JDBC4 version. If you are using 1.7 or 1.8 then you should use the JDBC41 version.
{quote}
Since Bamboo 5.9, Java 8 is supported, but we still ship with PostgreSQL 9.3 JDBC4

h3.Workaround
Download the JDBC41 driver from http://jdbc.postgresql.org/download.html and replace the existing PostgreSQL driver in _$Bamboo_Install/lib/_
fields.summary: Bamboo is shipped with Postgres JDBC4 instead of JDBC41

fields.description:
I have set up and integrated Bamboo with Jira behind a reverse proxy (NGINX) which is terminating SSL. Behind the reverse proxy, in the private subnet all applications are communicating over http.

This means that the Application URLs are configured as *+http+*://192.168... while the Display URLs are configured as *+https+*://jira.mydomain....

Now, when Bamboo display a link to a JIRA issue, the icon images cannot be downloaded because they are rendered as http://192.168.../ (see , MissingImages, WronkLink.PNG), which of course can't be resolved.

IMHO, the links rendered on a web page should always be derived from the Display URL.
fields.summary: Images of linked JIRA issues are rendered with the wrong link

fields.description:
Bamboo currently will currently set it's default timeout to be that of the Tomcat server, which by default is 30 min.  The session will be invalidated when there is no activity for the specified period.  However, when a user is on a page that continually polls the server for updates (such as a dashboard with builds) the session is always considered active - and will effectively prevent time out. 

An improvement for Bamboo would be to be able to specify a time period that can be set in the UI that will force the invalidation of the login, regardless of the session activity.
fields.summary: Force logout after a specified period

fields.description:
Some customers experience extensive delays when cloning a git repository. Currently when Bamboo fails to update a caches git repository we clear the cache, and re-sync from scratch.  This can be troublesome for some customers with large repositories. 

An improvement for Bamboo would be to stop the build and warn that the repo has not been able to be checked out, allowing investigation by the customer, rather than cycling through repeated clear/sync attempts.
fields.summary: Provide warning when internal git cache can not be correctly synced
